summary: Lee S. Strickland was a CIA official involved in discussions and decisions concerning the release of CIA records related to the JFK assassination to the Assassination Records Review Board (ARRB) between April and September 1998. His work focused on protecting sensitive information during the ARRB's review process, including cryptonyms, pseudonyms, file numbers, and employee names. Strickland's involvement extended to issues such as the release of information about the Warrenton Training Center (WTC), the CIA Record Center location, the opening date of Nosenko NBR material, the release of information on CIA employees under State cover, the handling of Cuban Revolutionary Council (CRC) financial records, personnel files, non-related files in the Sequestered Collection, covert actions, alias documentation, Mexico City tapes, and a CIA penetration of the Cuban Embassy (LITAMIL-9).
significance: Medium. Lee S. Strickland appears to have played a significant role in the CIA's management and release of JFK assassination records to the ARRB. His involvement in a variety of sensitive issues suggests a position of responsibility within the CIA during this period. The number of documents mentioning him (11) further supports this assessment.
